awd_titl_txt: Deciphering and reprogramming light induced double bond isomerization in proteins
awd_abstract_narration:
Massimo Olivucci of Bowling Green State University (BGSU) is supported by an award from the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division to develop, benchmark, and apply a second-generation computational framework for modeling light-responsive proteins and tuning their properties via controlled sequence mutations. Only two biological systems are capable of exploiting light as a source of energy: chlorophyll systems and rhodopsins. Chlorophyll systems are complex, composed of dozens of protein and pigment molecules. Rhodopsins, on the other hand, consist of one protein and one retinal molecule assembled in a simple architecture. In spite of such simplicity, rhodopsins carry out a variety of important light-powered functions such as ion-pumping, ion-channeling and color-sensing in microorganisms, and vision in invertebrates and vertebrates. These photoswitchable properties are of enormous interest in tailoring proteins for use as specialized probes, actuators, and switches. This research uses a sensory rhodopsin from the cyanobacterium Anabaena as a reference system. Professor Olivucci's ARM (Automatic Rhodopsin Model) protocol is used to construct a large number of computationally "mutated" rhodopsins, involving an artificial amino acid substitution in the protein sequence. ARM is used to simulate the mutated protein using a combination of classical and advanced quantum mechanical techniques, and predict the relationship between the changes in protein sequence and specific responses to light. Large numbers of mutated rhodopsins can be computationally generated and simulated in parallel, enormously extending the range and diversity of variants that can be explored. This project will extend ARM to predict a range of new properties, with the goal of developing a systematic theory of rhodopsin light sensitivity for application to fluorescence microscopy, molecular evolution, and optogenetics. ARM is being implemented by BGSU students as an online web-based server to facilitate open student and researcher access to the protocol. This will allow high school students and undergraduates to generate and explore sophisticated, atomic-scale rhodopsin models without requiring significant theoretical background. Professor Olivucci is integrating ARM into the BGSU graduate program in photochemical science, to provide a novel introduction to structural and functional photobiology using molecular visualization techniques complemented by 3D printing capabilities.  

This aim of this project is to understand how proteins control elementary photochemical reactions by developing a novel computational technology. Building on Professor Olivucci's ARM protocol for the fast and automated construction of QM/MM models of light-responsive proteins, a more accurate, second-generation version will be developed featuring free energy calculation capabilities and an expanded benchmark set. The goal is to learn how to reprogram protein spectroscopy and thermochemical and photochemical reactivity by tailoring the chemical properties of a protein reference system---in this project, a sensory rhodopsin from the cyanobacterium Anabaena. The construction and analysis of sets of mutated models and their experimental verification are expected to reveal novel engineering principles. More specifically, and together with external collaborators, Professor Olivucci is learning how mutations may control the excited state isomerization dynamics and lifetime of the system and, among other applications, to use this knowledge to design, and express in the laboratory, fluorescent rhodopsins that could be employed as sensors in optogenetics. Specific aims of the research include computationally screening large numbers of Anabaena sensory rhodopsin (ASR) mutants, searching for ASR mutants exhibiting longer excited state lifetimes, and improving the accuracy, applicability and automation of ARM to a level suitable for dissemination and broad use by the scientific community.

por.por_cntn:
Neuroscience is presently undergoing remarkable adavancements due to the introduction of optogenetic tools. These are based on the etherologous expression of microbial rhodopsins in neurons and on the exploitation of they light-responsive properties for either triggering, silencing or visualizing brain signals at the neuronal level. The design of more effective optogentic tools is presently slow and costly. The proposed research was based on the general idea that computational photochemistry and photobiology methods can: 1) greatly enhance the search for improved and diverse optogentic tools, 2) allow the atomic-level description of the rhodopsin light-response and 3) help to define novel and more effective ways to engineer rhodopsins (i.e. uncover/define engineering rules). The deliverables 1-3 all have, as a key step, the production of multiscale (QM/MM) models of rhodopsin proteins.

During the initial efforts necessary to achieve 1-3, we realized that the manual building of the necessary rhodopsin QM/MM models: (i) strongly slowed down our progress and (ii) introduce operator/user random errors that could only be discovered and fixed after further time-consuming research work. To avoid these drawbacks, we invested a large part of research time in writing and benchmarking an original software (a computer program) that could automate the QM/MM model building. We called such software a-ARM. This extreme effort was successful at the level that we were able to create a web-page that allowed external users to run the calculations neccessary for automated rhodopsin QM/MM model construction (Web-ARM) and provide a service to the scientific community.

The automated QM/MM building protocol for rhodopsins has been initially benchmarked on absorption properties. This means that we realized that the a-ARM computational tool was able to predict, within a certain error bar, the color of the absorbed light by different microbial and animal rhodopsins or from the variants of a specific rhodopsin engineered in the laboratory (the so called color-tuning properties). Once our models were validate for light-color absorption, we passed to a second phase focusing on the optogenetically important property of light (fluorescence) emission. The fluorescence emission is exploted in the visualization of the nerve impulses at the neuronal or neuronal networks levels. Our atomatically built models were shown to succesfully reproduce also the emission properties, thus opening the path to the computer-aided engineering of novel optogenetic becons (also called reporters).

In conclusion, the funded research has generated an original computational technology that automates the construction of QM/MM rhodopsin models suitable for the investigation of trends in spectroscopic and photochemical properties in different sets of rhodopsins. In a final effort, we have been able to demonstrate that such validated models (in the sense that they reproduce experimentally observed property trends) provide an asset for the in-depth investigation of light driven regulatory mechanisms at the atomistic level. In other words, we have shown that we can, not only predict color tuning and emission intensity trends, but also find out what are the atomistic and electronic factors that cause the observed behavior. Thus the research has also resulted in a major progress in the understanding and, possibly, rational engineering of rhodopsin properties. More specifically, our automated computational technology has revealed how variation in the internal rhodopsin electrostatics could be related to the changes in the absorbed or emitted light color, to the changes in fluorescence intensities and, finally, to the changes in photoisomerization efficiencies. These achievements are general and do not apply exclusively to optogenetic tools but apply to the entire set of light-triggered rhodopsin functions including, primarily, that of the vertebrate retina visual pigment that are specialized rhodopin molecules. Therefore we believe that significant progress has also been done towards the general study of both microbial and animal rhodopsin proteins and their different functions.
